title: Setup Local to Develop WordPress Site Locally in Fedora
excerpt: Local  is a development tool to develop WordPress sites locally. It provides many useful features to initiate a new site, do backup and many more.  It supports various operating systems including macOS, Windows, Debian and rpm-based Linux systems. This ar...

text.content: Local

rich_text.plain_text: Local

text.content: is a development tool to develop WordPress sites locally. It provides many useful features to initiate a new site, do backup and many more.  It supports various operating systems including macOS, Windows, Debian and rpm-based Linux systems. This article describes the steps to set up and use Local in

rich_text.plain_text: is a development tool to develop WordPress sites locally. It provides many useful features to initiate a new site, do backup and many more.  It supports various operating systems including macOS, Windows, Debian and rpm-based Linux systems. This article describes the steps to set up and use Local in

text.content: Fedora

rich_text.plain_text: Fedora

text.content: Attention! Local can’t be installed in Fedora 37 and above because the missing

rich_text.plain_text: Attention! Local can’t be installed in Fedora 37 and above because the missing

text.content: ncurses-compat-libs

rich_text.plain_text: ncurses-compat-libs

text.content: package. You can follow this thread about the reason Fedora remove this package:

rich_text.plain_text: package. You can follow this thread about the reason Fedora remove this package:

text.content: , seems like fixing this issue is a low priority for now. So, for the reset of article, we use Fedora 36.

text.content: Install Local

rich_text.plain_text: Install Local

text.content: Visit

rich_text.plain_text: Visit

text.content: https://localwp.com/releases

rich_text.plain_text: https://localwp.com/releases

text.content: , then download Local as an rpm package.

rich_text.plain_text: , then download Local as an rpm package.

text.content: Install Local by double-clicking the rpm file, then click “Install”

rich_text.plain_text: Install Local by double-clicking the rpm file, then click “Install”

text.content: When installation finished, click “Open” to launch the app

rich_text.plain_text: When installation finished, click “Open” to launch the app

text.content: Read the terms of service, then tick the checkbox and click “I agree”

rich_text.plain_text: Read the terms of service, then tick the checkbox and click “I agree”

text.content: Turn on error reporting if you want

rich_text.plain_text: Turn on error reporting if you want

text.content: installation finished. Click the close button (top right corner) if you want to use Local without creating an account. Click “Create a free account” or visit

rich_text.plain_text: installation finished. Click the close button (top right corner) if you want to use Local without creating an account. Click “Create a free account” or visit

text.content: https://localwp.com/

rich_text.plain_text: https://localwp.com/

text.content:
to use Local with an account.
I recommend creating an account to unlock useful features like Live Link, Cloud Backups and many more.

rich_text.plain_text:
to use Local with an account.
I recommend creating an account to unlock useful features like Live Link, Cloud Backups and many more.

text.content: Here’s what the fresh installation of Local looks like. Click “Create a new site” or the plus (+) button on the bottom left corner to create a WordPress project

rich_text.plain_text: Here’s what the fresh installation of Local looks like. Click “Create a new site” or the plus (+) button on the bottom left corner to create a WordPress project

text.content: Start a New WordPress Project

rich_text.plain_text: Start a New WordPress Project

text.content: Open the Local app and click “Create a new site” or the plus (+) button on the bottom left corner of the window.

rich_text.plain_text: Open the Local app and click “Create a new site” or the plus (+) button on the bottom left corner of the window.

text.content: Select “Create a new site” to start with a fresh WordPress installation, then click “Continue”

rich_text.plain_text: Select “Create a new site” to start with a fresh WordPress installation, then click “Continue”

text.content: Set the site name. By default, Local will prefills the domain name and the path of the project. We can still adjust it when needed.

rich_text.plain_text: Set the site name. By default, Local will prefills the domain name and the path of the project. We can still adjust it when needed.

text.content: Choose the environment. Use the “Preferred” option if there are no special requirements. Otherwise, choose “Custom”.

rich_text.plain_text: Choose the environment. Use the “Preferred” option if there are no special requirements. Otherwise, choose “Custom”.

text.content: Define username, password and e-mail, then click “Add Site”

rich_text.plain_text: Define username, password and e-mail, then click “Add Site”

text.content: Wait until the process is finished. Sometimes, we need to input our login credentials to allow Local execution. When the installation is finished, our site will be automatically started.

rich_text.plain_text: Wait until the process is finished. Sometimes, we need to input our login credentials to allow Local execution. When the installation is finished, our site will be automatically started.

text.content: When finished, click the “WP Admin” button to open the admin login page, and “Open site” to visit the site.

rich_text.plain_text: When finished, click the “WP Admin” button to open the admin login page, and “Open site” to visit the site.

text.content: Go to the “Database” tab and click “Open Adminer” to open the database explorer.

rich_text.plain_text: Go to the “Database” tab and click “Open Adminer” to open the database explorer.

text.content: Now, we can start the development of our site.

rich_text.plain_text: Now, we can start the development of our site.

text.content: Back-Up a Local Site to The Cloud

rich_text.plain_text: Back-Up a Local Site to The Cloud

text.content: Local supports integration with Dropbox or Google Drives to back up our site. This is one of my favourite features because we can back up the whole site including the database with a simple action. Follow these steps to enable Cloud Backups feature.

rich_text.plain_text: Local supports integration with Dropbox or Google Drives to back up our site. This is one of my favourite features because we can back up the whole site including the database with a simple action. Follow these steps to enable Cloud Backups feature.

text.content: Make sure we already have a Local account. Visit

rich_text.plain_text: Make sure we already have a Local account. Visit

text.content: https://localwp.com/

rich_text.plain_text: https://localwp.com/

text.content: to create an account.

rich_text.plain_text: to create an account.

text.content: Login into Local from

rich_text.plain_text: Login into Local from

text.content: https://hub.localwp.com/login

rich_text.plain_text: https://hub.localwp.com/login

text.content: Go to the Cloud Backups menu, then connect any storage.

rich_text.plain_text: Go to the Cloud Backups menu, then connect any storage.

text.content: Now we need to install the

rich_text.plain_text: Now we need to install the

text.content: Cloud Backups add-on

rich_text.plain_text: Cloud Backups add-on

text.content: . It can be installed from the desktop app, but I recommend installing it manually using git because installing from the app takes a very long time and we can’t see the actual progress.

rich_text.plain_text: . It can be installed from the desktop app, but I recommend installing it manually using git because installing from the app takes a very long time and we can’t see the actual progress.

text.content: Installation takes a long time without a progress indicator. We can’t see if the process is still running or already failed.

caption.plain_text: Installation takes a long time without a progress indicator. We can’t see if the process is still running or already failed.

text.content: To install manually, we need Node.js and Yarn to be installed. Use a version manager like

rich_text.plain_text: To install manually, we need Node.js and Yarn to be installed. Use a version manager like

text.content: asdf

rich_text.plain_text: asdf

text.content: or

rich_text.plain_text: or

text.content: nvm

rich_text.plain_text: nvm

text.content: because we need a specific version of Node.js to avoid errors due to incompatibility in version 17 and newer. I recommend asdf because we can manage versions for many development tools using it.

rich_text.plain_text: because we need a specific version of Node.js to avoid errors due to incompatibility in version 17 and newer. I recommend asdf because we can manage versions for many development tools using it.

text.content: Error in Node.js v17 or newer.

caption.plain_text: Error in Node.js v17 or newer.

text.content: Install Node.js and Yarn using asdf:

rich_text.plain_text: Install Node.js and Yarn using asdf:

text.content: Follow this guide to install asdf:

rich_text.plain_text: Follow this guide to install asdf:

text.content: https://asdf-vm.com/guide/getting-started.html#_1-install-dependencies

rich_text.plain_text: https://asdf-vm.com/guide/getting-started.html#_1-install-dependencies

text.content: Install Node.js and Yarn

rich_text.plain_text: Install Node.js and Yarn

text.content:
asdf plugin-add nodejs
asdf install nodejs 16.9.1
asdf global nodejs 16.9.1

asdf plugin-add yarn
asdf install yarn 1.22.19
asdf global yarn 1.22.19

rich_text.plain_text:
asdf plugin-add nodejs
asdf install nodejs 16.9.1
asdf global nodejs 16.9.1

asdf plugin-add yarn
asdf install yarn 1.22.19
asdf global yarn 1.22.19

text.content: Install

rich_text.plain_text: Install

text.content: git-lfs

rich_text.plain_text: git-lfs

text.content:
sudo dnf install git-lfs
git-lfs install

rich_text.plain_text:
sudo dnf install git-lfs
git-lfs install

text.content: Clone the repo into the Local addons directory. It will take a long time because the addon includes large binary files. That’s why we need to install git-lfs in the first place.

rich_text.plain_text: Clone the repo into the Local addons directory. It will take a long time because the addon includes large binary files. That’s why we need to install git-lfs in the first place.

text.content:
git clone https://github.com/getflywheel/local-addon-backups.git ~/.config/Local/addons/local-addon-backups
cd ~/.config/Local/addons/local-addon-backups
git lfs pull

rich_text.plain_text:
git clone https://github.com/getflywheel/local-addon-backups.git ~/.config/Local/addons/local-addon-backups
cd ~/.config/Local/addons/local-addon-backups
git lfs pull

text.content: Build the addon

rich_text.plain_text: Build the addon

text.content:
yarn install
yarn build

rich_text.plain_text:
yarn install
yarn build

text.content: Activate the addon from the desktop app by opening the Add-ons menu from the left sidebar, visiting the Installed tab, then toggling on the Cloud Backups addon. A message will be prompted on the top of the screen, then click Relaunch.

rich_text.plain_text: Activate the addon from the desktop app by opening the Add-ons menu from the left sidebar, visiting the Installed tab, then toggling on the Cloud Backups addon. A message will be prompted on the top of the screen, then click Relaunch.

text.content: Now, when any Local site is started, we can create a backup.

rich_text.plain_text: Now, when any Local site is started, we can create a backup.

text.content: That’s all about setting up the basic functionality of Local to make WordPress development easier. Hope this helps!

rich_text.plain_text: That’s all about setting up the basic functionality of Local to make WordPress development easier. Hope this helps!
